snippet: Even as European military observers held as suspected NATO spies were released Saturday, Russia cited bloody street violence in Odessa as proof that Ukraine could no longer protect its citizens.
abstract: Ukraine's security forces press their assault to try to reclaim pro-Russian stronghold of Slovyansk, even as European military observers held as suspected NATO spies are released; Russia cites bloody street violence in Odessa as proof that Ukraine can no longer protect its citizens.

byline.original: By ALISON SMALE and ANDREW E. KRAMER
byline.contributor: Alison Smale reported from Kiev, and Andrew E. Kramer from Donetsk, Ukraine. Reporting was contributed by C. J. Chivers and Noah Sneider from Slovyansk, Ukraine; Sergey Ponomarev from Kramatorsk, Ukraine; Neil MacFarquhar and Alexandra Odynova from Moscow; Michael R. Gordon from Kinshasa, Democratic Republic of Congo; and Melissa Eddy from Berlin.

lead_paragraph: Even as European military observers held as suspected NATO spies were released Saturday, Russia cited bloody street violence in Odessa as proof that Ukraine could no longer protect its citizens.

headline.main: Ukraine Presses Pro-Russia Militants After Fighting Spreads to a Port City
headline.print_headline: Ukraine Presses Pro-Russia Militants After Fighting Spreads to a Port City

keywords.value: Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe
keywords.name: organizations
